intro: Arthraxon raizadae, commonly known as the mountain sedge, is a flowering plant native to the high-altitude regions of South America. It belongs to the Cyperaceae family, which includes grass-like plants known for their ecological importance in wetlands and disturbed soils. The plant features narrow, grass-like leaves and produces small, clustered flower spikes that bloom in late summer. It is adapted to cold, nutrient-poor environments and plays a role in stabilizing mountainous terrain. Its botanical characteristics make it an important species for studying plant adaptations to extreme climates.
